study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of abdominal massage on gastric function in preterm infants to alleviate gastrointestinal problems.
results_summary: The study found that abdominal massage significantly improved gastric function in preterm infants, evidenced by reduced vomiting episodes, residual volume, and improved defecation frequency, though weight gain was not significantly affected.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gastrointestinal problems.
effective_dosage: 15-minute abdominal massage before feeding, twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of multi-component interventions, including massage, on sleep outcomes among older adults.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence for the efficacy of multi-component interventions (including massage) in improving sleep outcomes, such as sleep quality and characteristics, in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 50 and above.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of non-pharmacological therapies, including massage, for pain management in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy demonstrated a reduction in pain perception, attributed to tactile stimulation and the release of anti-nociceptive molecules, though the literature on its effectiveness is limited.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients experiencing pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of preventive interventions, including massage, to reduce preterm birth among pregnant women with psychosocial vulnerability factors.
results_summary: The study identified massage as one of the interventions examined, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy results for massage alone. The overall evidence base for interventions, including massage, was found to be limited, with group meetings facilitated by a midwife showing the greatest likelihood of effectiveness.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with psychosocial vulnerability factors.

study_goal: To review the knowledge, attitudes, and practices of non-medical professionals (NMPs), including massage therapists, regarding skin cancer detection and referral.
results_summary: NMPs are open to examining clients' skin and willing to refer suspicious lesions for physician evaluation. Educational interventions improved their ability to identify skin cancers and refer appropriately.
population_specificity: Non-medical professionals (massage therapists, estheticians, hairdressers, cosmetologists).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage therapy as a non-pharmacological method for managing pain in neonates undergoing painful medical procedures.
results_summary: The review found that massage therapy consistently reduced pain intensity in neonates across all included studies, though the methods of implementation varied widely in terms of body part massaged, duration, intensity, and combination with other techniques. Positive outcomes were reported in all studies, suggesting massage is an effective analgesic method.
population_specificity: Neonates undergoing painful medical procedures in nine countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects and reliability of sham procedures in manual therapy trials, including massage, for treating back pain and to provide methodological guidance for future clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that massage showed clinically insignificant pain improvement compared to sham treatment, with no significant differences between sham treatment and no treatment. Adverse effects and drop-out rates were similar between massage and sham treatment.
population_specificity: Adults affected by acute or chronic back pain (cervical and lumbar).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of self-massage and other remote interventions in managing orofacial pain related to TMD and bruxism during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study found that self-massage, along with other remote treatments like stretching and relaxation techniques, could help manage chronic orofacial pain at its initial stage, particularly when in-person dental care was limited during the pandemic. Psycho-emotional stress exacerbated TMD and bruxism symptoms, but remote interventions provided a viable alternative for pain relief.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from temporomandibular disorders (TMD) and bruxism during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of non-pharmacological interventions, including massage, on preoperative anxiety and acute postoperative pain in women undergoing breast cancer surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not specify the effects of massage, only mentioning that music, aromatherapy, and acupuncture were effective for reducing preoperative anxiety and postoperative pain.
population_specificity: Women undergoing breast cancer surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pre-competition massage on neuromuscular function, specifically focusing on the gastrocnemius muscle.
results_summary: The study found that pre-competition massage significantly increased contraction time (Tc) and maximal radial displacement (Dm) while reducing stiffness and tone in the gastrocnemius muscle. However, the abstract notes that more quality studies are needed for clear conclusions.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify non-pharmacological therapies, including massage, applied during pregnancy and labor to reduce labor-related effects such as pain, duration, and anxiety.
results_summary: Massage was among the non-pharmacological therapies found to have positive outcomes, including pain reduction in labor and improvements in variables like labor duration, anxiety, and pelvic floor laceration rates. Six articles (60%) supported its efficacy for pain reduction.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals during pregnancy and labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize provider-focused research on complementary and integrative medicine (CIM), including massage, in palliative care to map existing evidence and identify knowledge gaps.
results_summary: The study identified massage as one of the most investigated CIM modalities (n = 13), used to address common symptoms like pain (n = 17), fatigue (n = 6), and nausea/vomiting (n = 6). Outcomes included perceived benefits of CIM (n = 17) and types of CIM modalities providers offer (n = 15).
population_specificity: Palliative care providers, primarily nurses (n = 29) and physicians (n = 22).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot massages given by mothers could reduce pain and increase comfort in newborns undergoing heel lancing.
results_summary: The study found that foot massage performed by mothers reduced pain levels, increased comfort, and decreased distress in newborns during heel lancing. The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Newborns undergoing heel lancing (sample size: 128, with 64 in the intervention group and 64 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 3-minute foot massage with baby oil immediately before the procedure.

study_goal: To assess the effect of therapeutic massage, particularly Tuina, on improving motor function and reducing spasticity in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic massage, especially Tuina combined with conventional physiotherapy, significantly improved upper limb motor function and reduced spasticity in stroke survivors, with a mean difference of 2.75 on the Fugl Meyer Assessment.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of non-pharmacological measures, including massage, in managing symptoms of restless legs syndrome (RLS).
results_summary: The study found that some individuals with RLS achieved adequate symptom control using non-pharmacological interventions such as massage, though the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data or comparative analysis with other treatments.
population_specificity: Individuals with restless legs syndrome (RLS), including those with primary or secondary forms related to conditions like iron deficiency or chronic renal insufficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop clinical practice guidelines for sensory motor stimulation, including massage, in newborns and infants in intensive care units, focusing on safety, efficacy, and tailored interventions.
results_summary: Tactile-kinesthetic massage and multisensory stimulation were found to improve weight gain and sucking in newborns and infants, with all modalities showing positive effects on pain and stress control.
population_specificity: Preterm and term newborns, as well as infants aged 28 days to 6 months, hospitalized in intensive care units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term and long-term effectiveness of distal fibular mobilization with movement (MWM), MWM with tape (MWMtape), and anteroposterior mobilization of the talus (MOB) in treating acute lateral ankle sprains.
results_summary: MWM and MWMtape were equally effective and showed better long-term function (12 and 52 weeks) compared to MOB, though MOB provided superior short-term sport function at 2 weeks. No differences were observed in secondary outcomes or patient global impression of improvement.
population_specificity: 45 amateur soccer players with acute (<72 hours) lateral ankle sprains.
effective_dosage: 6 sessions (3 per week within the first 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of negative pressure massage treatment (NPMT) versus manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) in improving lymphedema and upper limb function in women with chronic breast cancer-related lymphedema.
results_summary: NPMT showed significantly greater improvement in L-Dex scores and interlimb volume differences compared to MLD, with large effect sizes, though no significant difference was found in DASH scores. The findings suggest NPMT may be more effective for certain lymphedema outcomes.
population_specificity: Women aged >18 with unilateral arm lymphedema for ≥1 year after breast cancer treatment, not receiving lymphedema care, and with stable lymphedema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of "three-dimensional balanced manipulation" (TBM) versus traditional massage in treating cervical spondylotic radiculopathy (CSR) and to analyze the biomechanical mechanisms of TBM.
results_summary: The TBM group showed a significantly higher total effective rate compared to the control group (traditional massage). Biomechanical analysis revealed stress and deformation patterns in the cervical spine, suggesting TBM's effectiveness in CSR treatment.
population_specificity: 120 patients with cervical spondylotic radiculopathy (CSR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of machine-based hand massage on preoperative anxiety and vital signs in ambulatory surgery patients.
results_summary: Machine-based hand massage significantly reduced preoperative anxiety in the experimental group compared to the control group, with no significant changes in vital signs except for a slight increase in respiration rate in both groups. Blood pressure decreased significantly only in the control group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory surgery patients aged 18 years and older from Taipei Municipal Wanfang Hospital in Taipei City, Taiwan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of aromatherapy, including massage, on improving sleep quality in individuals with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that aromatherapy significantly improved sleep quality, but the massage group did not show an obvious therapeutic effect, possibly due to the small number of included studies using massage.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia from various countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of foot massage with lavender and orange essential oils on sleep quality and restless leg syndrome (RLS) in hemodialysis (HD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that foot massage with lavender and orange essential oils significantly improved sleep quality and reduced RLS symptoms in HD patients compared to the control group, with consistent results across all measurement times (p<0.001).
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients in a large educational hospital in Iran.
effective_dosage: Foot massage with essential oils administered three times a week for three weeks, each session lasting half an hour.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of classical massage (CM) combined with cervical stabilization exercise (CSE) versus kinesio taping (KT) combined with CSE in improving disability, pain, range of motion, and quality of life in patients with chronic neck pain.
results_summary: The study found that CM + CSE was superior to KT + CSE in improving cervical rotation movements, while KT + CSE showed better outcomes in reducing disability and improving quality of life. Both interventions demonstrated improvements, but the effects varied by outcome measure.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic value of Massage and other CIH modalities in managing chronic pain within a multidisciplinary rehabilitation framework.
results_summary: The study found that self-massage, among other CIH therapies, is significantly effective for managing chronic pain with little to no negative effects and can be easily incorporated into telemedicine care.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients, particularly within the Veterans Affairs (VA) Healthcare system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of multiple rounds of traditional Thai massage (TTM) on senescent CD4+ T cell subsets in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that TTM attenuated senescent CD4+ T cell subsets, particularly in CD4+28, suggesting potential immune-modulatory benefits in the elderly.
population_specificity: Elderly volunteers aged 61-75 years with senescent CD4+ T cell subsets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding arch-support foot-orthoses (ASFO) to a multimodal therapeutic intervention, including ice massage, improved pain and recovery in recreational runners with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS).
results_summary: The study found that ASFO combined with multimodal therapy (including ice massage) reduced pain and MTSS severity and improved perceived treatment effects and physical function at weeks 6 and 12, but these benefits did not persist at week 18.
population_specificity: Fifty female recreational runners with MTSS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the evidence base supporting nonpharmacologic pain control methods, including massage, for patients with inflammatory arthritis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage is one of several nonpharmacologic modalities considered for pain control in inflammatory arthritis, but specific findings about its effectiveness are not detailed. The discussion implies a general support for such interventions within a broader pain management framework.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory arthritis (e.g., peripheral spondyloarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of foot massage with orange essential oil on anxiety in women undergoing cesarean section.
results_summary: Foot massage with orange essential oil significantly reduced anxiety scores immediately after and 60 minutes post-intervention compared to the control group, which saw a rebound in anxiety. The intervention group showed sustained anxiety reduction.
population_specificity: 80 women who underwent cesarean section at Bahar Shahroud Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent trends in occupational allergic contact dermatitis (ACD), including allergens relevant to massage therapists and aromatherapists.
results_summary: The study found that lavender, limonene, and linalool, new additions to the ACDS Core Allergen Series, have been reported as causes for occupational ACD in massage therapists and aromatherapists.
population_specificity: Massage therapists and aromatherapists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the transformation of integrative oncology services, including massage, from in-person to virtual formats during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study noted a shift from in-person massage services to virtual self-care massage, with an overall increase in patient engagement in virtual integrative oncology programs. No specific efficacy data for massage were provided, but virtual delivery was deemed feasible and appealing.
population_specificity: Cancer patients at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of massage and touch therapy with other drug and non-drug interventions for reducing symptoms of depression in people with dementia.
results_summary: Massage and touch therapy were associated with a significant reduction in depressive symptoms (-9.03 on the Cornell scale) compared to usual care and were more efficacious than some drug interventions. The effect was statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: People with dementia experiencing symptoms of depression but without a diagnosis of major depressive disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nursing interventions, including hand massage, in managing preoperative anxiety in adults.
results_summary: The study found that nursing interventions, including hand massage, had a positive impact on reducing preoperative anxiety, with the meta-analysis showing a mean difference in favor of the intervention. However, the low number of studies and sample heterogeneity suggest the need for further research.
population_specificity: Adults (>18 years) undergoing various types of surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether massage with emollient therapy (sunflower oil) leads to greater increases in weight and length compared to massage alone in preterm and low birth weight neonates.
results_summary: The study found that neonates receiving massage with emollient therapy (sunflower oil) showed significantly greater increases in weight (489.84 ± 297.48 grams vs. 373.43 ± 276.31 grams) and length (6.5 ± 1.1 cm vs. 4.8 ± 1.3 cm) compared to those receiving massage alone. The differences were statistically significant (p = 0.018 for weight, p < 0.001 for length).
population_specificity: Preterm and low birth weight neonates (birth weight 1.5-2.5 kg or gestational age 28-37 weeks).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mothers were advised to massage with sunflower oil, but frequency and amount were not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up at two months of age (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish consensus on the use of tilt table testing (TTT) and other provocative cardiovascular autonomic tests, including carotid sinus massage, for diagnosing transient loss of consciousness (TLOC).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding the effects of massage; it focuses on the diagnostic use of TTT and related tests.
population_specificity: Patients with disorders causing transient loss of consciousness (TLOC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects and safety of therapeutic ultrasound, including its combination with other treatments like massage, on neck pain.
results_summary: Therapeutic ultrasound combined with other treatments (e.g., massage) showed additional benefits for pain reduction, but effects on disability or quality of life were unclear. Compared to sham or no treatment, therapeutic ultrasound significantly reduced pain intensity.
population_specificity: Patients with neck pain (705 participants across 12 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the treatments, including massage, used by individuals with traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) for non-neuropathic pains (nonNeuPs) and assess their perceived helpfulness.
results_summary: Massage was among the most commonly used non-pharmacological treatments for nonNeuPs and was rated as one of the most helpful, with 71-80% of participants reporting it as beneficial for their pain. The perceived helpfulness varied by pain location, suggesting different mechanisms may underlie pains in different areas.
population_specificity: Individuals at least 1-year post-traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) from six Spinal Cord Injury Model Systems centers.
study_duration: Treatments were assessed over the previous 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of various types of ultrasound therapy (UST) combined with conventional physiotherapy (including massage) on pain, function, and quality of life in patients with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Massage was part of conventional physiotherapy, which showed significant improvements in resting pain, function (6-minute walking test), and quality of life (SF-36) across all treatment groups, though no additional benefit was observed from UST. The highest functional improvement was seen in the group combining UST with TENS.
population_specificity: Patients with hip osteoarthritis (n=71).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated for massage, but follow-up was at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hand and foot massage could reduce fatigue in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that both hand and foot massage significantly reduced fatigue scores compared to the control group, with statistical significance (p < 0.05). The results suggest massage is effective for fatigue reduction in this population.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients in a Turkish public hospital.
study_duration: Conducted between October 19, 2018, and February 11, 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if suboccipital fascial release (SFR) could influence heart rate variability (HRV) parameters in workers in the clothing industry as a means to reduce stress.
results_summary: The study found that SFR significantly improved HRV parameters such as sympathovagal balance, mean RR intervals, and heart rate metrics in treated workers, suggesting it may help alleviate stress more effectively than rest alone. No significant changes were observed in the untreated group.
population_specificity: Forty women working in the clothing industry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of myofascial release maneuver (MLM) on postural sway in healthy men by targeting different lower limb muscle chains.
results_summary: The study found no immediate specific effects of MLM on postural sway in healthy men, with pre-post effects of MLM not differing from those of superficial massage.
population_specificity: Healthy men (average age 27.2 ± 4.7 years).
effective_dosage: 3-minute MLM application with skin pressure determined by visual analog scale (5-7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lavender essential oil massage improves sleep quality in critical care nurses.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall subjective or objective sleep quality between the experimental and control groups, though a gradual reduction in subjective sleep quality scores was observed in the massage group. The findings suggest limited efficacy of lavender massage for improving sleep in this population.
population_specificity: Critical care nurses (n=112)
effective_dosage: Four sessions of lavender essential oil massage (specific dosage not detailed)
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (four sessions administered)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) perspectives and biomedical findings on EH-SF52, including the role of massage as part of a multi-mechanistic management approach.
results_summary: The study mentions massage as one of the TCM management strategies for EH-SF52, targeting symptomatic alleviation and blood pressure reduction, but does not provide specific results or data on its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Individuals with essential hypertension presenting as "liver yang ascendant hyperactivity" (EH-SF52), characterized by symptoms like headache, dizziness, poor sleep quality, and irritability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review interventions, including massage, for improving sleep in adult caregivers.
results_summary: The study found that back massage may have beneficial effects on caregivers' sleep, but methodological shortcomings and heterogeneity in studies limit definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Adult informal caregivers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of granisetron and lidocaine injections for managing myofascial pain syndrome, with massage as a supplementary intervention.
results_summary: Both lidocaine and granisetron injections reduced neck pain and disability, with lidocaine being more effective. Massage was part of the post-injection care but its standalone efficacy was not evaluated.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged ≥18 with neck pain due to myofascial pain syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified for massage (used as supplementary care).
study_duration: Patients were instructed to perform massage for three or four days post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) techniques, including massage, for acute nonspecific low back pain (ANLBP) and demonstrate the utility of Bayesian network meta-analysis for mixed treatment comparisons.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant decrease in pain when various OMT techniques, including massage, were added to conventional treatment for ANLBP. However, high-velocity low-amplitude (HVLA) and mixed OMT protocols were ranked superior to conventional care alone.
population_specificity: Patients with acute nonspecific low back pain (ANLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate pediatric clinicians' knowledge, beliefs, and practices regarding Complementary and Integrative Medicine (CIM), including familiarity with massage.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of respondents were familiar with massage, but it did not assess massage's specific effects or outcomes. Nurses were more familiar with CIM therapies, including massage, compared to physicians.
population_specificity: Pediatric clinicians (Registered Nurses, Attendings, Fellows, Residents, Nurse Practitioners) from a US-based teaching hospital in Connecticut.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of hyperthermic massage and mechanical squeezing on patients with meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD), grouped by severity of gland loss.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in meibography scores, OSDI, TBUT, and meibum expressibility in both mild-to-moderate and severe MGD groups after treatment, with no significant difference in outcomes between severity groups. All patients collectively showed reduced meibography scores, OSDI, and corneal staining, alongside increased TBUT and meibum expressibility.
population_specificity: Patients with meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD), divided into mild-to-moderate (group 1) and severe (group 2) gland loss.
effective_dosage: Hyperthermic massage and mechanical squeezing once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a rolling intervention with a roller massager embedded within rest periods of a resistance training protocol on performance, perceived exertion, and muscle soreness.
results_summary: The roller-massager intervention reduced total workload and concentric power while increasing perceived exertion. It also reduced thigh circumference (indicating less muscle swelling) and delayed onset of muscle soreness (DOMS) from 24 to 120 hours post-workout.
population_specificity: 14 participants performing resistance training protocols.
effective_dosage: 60 seconds of rolling routine during 2-minute recovery periods between sets.
study_duration: Single session with follow-up assessments up to 120 hours post-workout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of myofascial self-release using a rigid roller on range of motion, pressure pain threshold, and hamstring strength in asymptomatic individuals, comparing two different intervention times (30 seconds vs. 2 minutes).
results_summary: Both intervention times (30 seconds and 2 minutes) significantly increased range of motion compared to baseline, but no significant differences were observed in pressure pain threshold or peak knee-flexion torque.
population_specificity: 40 asymptomatic university students aged 18-30 years.
effective_dosage: Foam roller application for 30 seconds (Group 1) and 2 minutes (Group 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pediatric massage combined with basic rehabilitation treatment for children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study designed a 12-week intervention comparing pediatric massage plus basic rehabilitation to basic rehabilitation alone, with outcomes measured at multiple intervals. The abstract suggests potential efficacy but does not report specific results, as it describes a planned trial rather than completed findings.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (n=182).
effective_dosage: Modified selective spinal massage method combined with basic rehabilitation, 5 days weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of instrument-assisted soft tissue mobilization (IASTM) combined with neuromuscular exercises versus classical massage with the same exercises on functionality in patients with mechanical neck pain and forward head posture.
results_summary: The study found that both IASTM with exercises and classical massage with exercises improved cervical range of motion, strength, and pain in the short term, but IASTM showed significantly greater improvements in cervical vertebral angle and neck disability index compared to massage. Pain reduction was significant in both groups, though more pronounced with IASTM.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with mechanical neck pain and forward head posture.
study_duration: Treatment period plus two- and four-week post-treatment follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a nanosized liposomal micronutrient-fortified body oil for transdermal supplementation, leveraging the traditional practice of infant oil massage to enhance neuro-motor development.
results_summary: The study described the development process of the fortified oil using a theory of change approach, highlighting feasibility assessment, scaling up technology, and community-based implementation. The intervention was shaped by formative work and pilot testing, suggesting potential benefits for transdermal nutrient delivery.
population_specificity: Infants in Indian communities practicing traditional oil massage.

study_goal: To determine the clinical relevance of Massage Therapy (MT) and Abdominal Hypopressive Gymnastics (AHG) on disability, pain intensity, quality of life, and lumbar mobility in patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CNSLBP).
results_summary: Massage Therapy and Abdominal Hypopressive Gymnastics reduced pain levels, increased lumbar mobility, and improved disability and quality of life in the short term. The combination of both therapies provided more benefits in terms of lumbar disability.
population_specificity: 60 adults with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CNSLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of Touch Massage (TM) as a non-pharmacological intervention for chronic pain patients, focusing on its effects on pain perception, comfort, well-being, and caregiver-patient relationships.
results_summary: The study expects TM to improve patients' perception of pain management, enhance comfort and well-being, and strengthen caregiver-patient communication. The qualitative part will explore patient and healthcare team satisfaction with the intervention.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from chronic pain.
effective_dosage: At least 4 sessions spread over two weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pestle needle therapy (a form of massage/acupuncture) is effective and safe for treating postpartum milk deficiency in cesarean section patients.
results_summary: The study suggests pestle needle therapy may increase milk secretion and excretion, with potential benefits for breastfeeding, though full results are pending as it is a randomized controlled trial in progress.
population_specificity: 128 patients with lactation insufficiency after cesarean section.
effective_dosage: Pestle needle operation on specific acupoints once daily for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Lamaze breathing training combined with nursing interventions, including massage, on maternal pain relief and childbirth outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that Lamaze breathing combined with nursing interventions (including massage) increased natural delivery rates, shortened labor duration, alleviated labor pain, and reduced postpartum bleeding.
population_specificity: Primiparas (first-time mothers)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness and safety of massage therapy for treating poststroke depression.
results_summary: The study plans to comprehensively summarize and evaluate the evidence on massage therapy's effectiveness and safety for poststroke depression, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with poststroke depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of petrissage massage (PM) and manual lymph drainage (MLD) on the biomechanical and viscoelastic properties of the rectus femoris muscle in healthy women after submaximal exercise.
results_summary: Both PM and MLD significantly reduced muscle tonus and stiffness, with PM showing additional benefits in relaxation time and creep values. MLD also improved relaxation time but not creep values. Both methods supported tissue recovery post-exercise.
population_specificity: 18 healthy female students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of the MOWOOT device, which provides intermittent colonic exo-peristalsis (ICE) treatment, for treating chronic constipation due to neurogenic bowel dysfunction or idiopathic causes with a high component of pelvic floor disorders.
results_summary: The study found that the ICE device significantly increased the number of complete bowel movements per week, reduced chronic constipation symptoms, improved quality of life, and facilitated a reduction in laxative use, with a high responder rate (>70%). Adverse events related to treatment were low (8.7%).
population_specificity: 92 adult patients with chronic constipation due to neurogenic bowel dysfunction or idiopathic causes with a high component of pelvic floor disorders.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up for 9 consecutive weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of massage therapy and aromatherapy on knee pain, morning stiffness, daily life function, and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The massage therapy group showed the highest initial pain score but the lowest pain score after 10 sessions. Massage therapy significantly improved performance in exercise and recreational activities compared to the control group, though no significant difference was found in quality of life.
population_specificity: 93 patients with knee osteoarthritis referred to a physical therapy clinic.
study_duration: 10 sessions (exact duration not specified, but interventions recommended for at least 6 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Mulligan mobilisation versus Cyriax approach in managing pain and functional disability in patients with subacute lateral epicondylitis.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed significant improvements in pain and functional disability after 4 weeks. Group A (Cyriax approach) had greater pain reduction, while Group B (Mulligan mobilisation) showed better functional improvement, though total scores did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients with subacute lateral epicondylitis (symptoms >2 weeks), mean age 35.27±7.30 years, 63.3% male.
effective_dosage: Not specified (describes techniques but not exact dosage/frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of foot massage on relieving pain and anxiety in patients who underwent anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF).
results_summary: Foot massage significantly reduced pain (NP-VAS) and anxiety (self-rating anxiety scale) in ACDF patients, with improved mental function in the intervention group. No significant difference was observed in neck disability index (NDI) reduction between groups.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent ACDF and were diagnosed with anxiety disorder at least six months before surgery.
effective_dosage: 10-minute foot massage daily using sweet almond oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining massage and warm compress (MassComp) during the second stage of labor compared to standard "hands-off" care in reducing perineal injury rates.
results_summary: The study found that MassComp significantly reduced perineal suturing rates (67% vs. 91% in controls), major perineal injury, and episiotomy rates while improving maternal satisfaction. The relative risk was 0.72 (95% CI 0.61-0.98).
population_specificity: Nulliparous women at term in a University hospital in Malaysia.
effective_dosage: Massage during pushing and warm compress between pushes (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention administered during the second stage of labor (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of abdominal massage and lifestyle training on constipation and distension in elderly stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that abdominal massage combined with lifestyle education significantly reduced abdominal circumference, improved defecation frequency, and enhanced food tolerance in elderly stroke patients compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with stroke at Qaem hospital in Mashhad, Iran.
effective_dosage: 15-minute abdominal massage twice daily using the "I LOV U" method.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current, validated patient-reported outcomes (PROs) specific to cancer-related pain to aid clinicians and researchers in evaluating the effectiveness of integrative interventions like massage.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that massage is an effective nonpharmacologic approach for cancer pain with low cost and minimal adverse events, and it highlights the importance of standardized PROs for assessing pain intensity and symptom burden.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer and cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of non-pharmacological treatments, including manual therapy (massage), for managing low back pain in athletes.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the efficacy of manual therapy (massage) for low back pain in athletes, though some treatments showed reductions in pain and disability.
population_specificity: Athletes with low back pain

study_goal: To determine whether traditional Chinese exercises combined with traditional Chinese massage improves lumbar instability compared to exercises alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining traditional Chinese exercises with massage significantly improved JOA scores, reduced ODI, and decreased lumbar vertebral laxity compared to exercises alone. The experimental group showed better outcomes than the control group.
population_specificity: Seventy patients with lumbar instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage as part of interventions to increase exclusive breastfeeding rates among young mothers in high-income countries.
results_summary: The study did not detect a statistically significant difference in exclusive breastfeeding rates at 3 months postpartum when massage was included as part of combined interventions. Peer counseling showed more promise than massage alone.
population_specificity: Young mothers in high-income countries, primarily the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological mechanisms of pediatric massage on intestinal flora and host metabolism in children with anorexia.
results_summary: The study will compare intestinal flora structure, fecal short-chain fatty acids, serum trace elements, urine D-xylose excretion, gastric motility, and hemoglobin levels between massage and control groups, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: Children with anorexia (n=60 per group) and healthy children (n=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute and late effects of five consecutive sessions of Swedish massage on hamstring flexibility and agility in female players with tight hamstrings.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in hamstring flexibility (measured via PSLR, AKET, PKET, and BSSR) in the experimental group receiving Swedish massage, with effects persisting for 5 days post-intervention. No significant changes were observed in agility for either group.
population_specificity: 34 female players with bilateral tight hamstrings.
effective_dosage: 7-minute massage per posterior thigh for 5 consecutive days.
study_duration: 5 days of massage followed by 5 days of no massage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aromatherapy with Damask rose, including massage, on reducing acute pain in adults.
results_summary: The study found that aromatherapy massage with Damask rose significantly reduced pain severity (WMD: -1.16; 95% CI [-1.57, -0.75]; P < 0.001), though the overall quality of evidence was low.
population_specificity: Adults with acute pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an additional six weeks of Swedish Massage Therapy (SMT) beyond the initial six weeks provided greater clinical and statistical benefit in reducing anxiety symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that HAM-A scores continued to decrease with an additional six weeks of SMT, but the greatest reduction occurred during the first six weeks. The results suggest that six weeks of twice-weekly SMT may be sufficient for most patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how massage therapy, among other interventions, could enhance mobility and physical function in older adults as part of maintaining healthspan.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that massage therapy may improve physical function both directly through biological mechanisms and indirectly via cognitive and socioemotional modulation, though specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Older adults in the United States and globally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review randomized controlled trials to assess the effect of abdominal massage on gastrointestinal functions.
results_summary: Abdominal massage alleviated constipation symptoms in some populations, improved gastrointestinal functions in intensive care patients, and reduced gastric residual volume, but showed no significant effects on laxative intake, nausea, vomiting, or ventilator-associated pneumonia. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis, cancer, elderly adults, constipation, skeletal traction, intensive care, and mechanical ventilation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a multi-component exercise program, including self-massage for myofascial release, on physical frailty and related variables in pre-frail older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group, which combined high-intensity resistance training with self-massage for myofascial release, showed improvements in physical frailty, muscle function, and functional performance over 12 weeks. No specific adverse effects or safety concerns related to massage were reported.
population_specificity: Pre-frail, community-dwelling older adults (n=50, mean age 75±7 years).
effective_dosage: Self-massage for myofascial release combined with high-intensity resistance training, 2 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combining a comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) with multi-disciplinary management, including acupoint massage in TCM, on frailty in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a multi-disciplinary approach, including acupoint massage, but specific results regarding massage's effects are not yet available as it describes a planned trial.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (≥70 years old) with frailty in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of abdominal massage on bowel evacuation and the risk of constipation in neurosurgical intensive care unit (NICU) patients.
results_summary: Abdominal massage significantly shortened the time of return of bowel sounds and the time of the first defecation compared to the control group, demonstrating its effectiveness as a nursing intervention for NICU patients. The risk of constipation was high in both groups, but massage improved outcomes.
population_specificity: Neurosurgical intensive care unit (NICU) patients.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes every morning and evening (total 30 minutes daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether back massage could improve physiological parameters, dyspnoea, and anxiety in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients receiving noninvasive mechanical ventilation in the ICU.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in physiological parameters or dyspnoea levels but reported a significant reduction in anxiety scores in the massage group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease receiving noninvasive mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of activity-oriented proprioceptive antiedema therapy (TAPA) versus conventional treatments like DLT or CPT for breast cancer-related arm lymphedema, including massage therapy.
results_summary: The study proposed combining neural mobilization techniques, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation, and cohesive bandaging to improve comfort and participation in daily activities for lymphedema patients, but specific results on massage therapy alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 64 women with breast cancer-related arm lymphedema (stages I and II).
effective_dosage: Not specified for massage therapy alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of massage therapy on term neonates with neonatal jaundice receiving phototherapy compared to a control group receiving only phototherapy.
results_summary: The study found that the massage group had significantly higher defecation frequency and lower serum bilirubin levels from day 3 onward compared to the control group, indicating massage therapy as a beneficial adjunct to phototherapy.
population_specificity: Term newborns with neonatal jaundice in Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence and provide optimal prescriptive recommendations for foam rolling and roller massage to improve range of motion (ROM) and performance.
results_summary: The study found that 1-3 sets of 2-4-second repetition durations with a total rolling duration of 30-120 seconds per set were most effective for improving ROM, while strength and jump performance showed trivial to small decreases. Insufficient evidence was available to generalize effects on fatigue and sprint measures.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from literature review)
effective_dosage: 1-3 sets of 2-4-second repetitions, 30-120 seconds per set

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of intramuscular methylergonovine maleate as prophylaxis against excessive bleeding after dilation and evacuation (D&E) at 20-24 weeks.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in the composite outcome for excessive bleeding with prophylactic methylergonovine, and individual excessive bleeding outcomes occurred more frequently in the methylergonovine group, suggesting potential harm.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing D&E at 20-24 weeks without excessive bleeding requiring intervention post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage or myofascial release in improving chronic musculoskeletal pain conditions such as low back pain, hip and knee osteoarthritis, and fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study found that massage or myofascial release yields a small improvement in low back pain, hip and knee osteoarthritis, and fibromyalgia. The benefits were modest but consistent across these conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain, hip and knee osteoarthritis, and fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining botulinum toxin therapy and dynamic electric neurostimulation with basic therapy (including massage and therapeutic exercises) in reducing post-stroke spasticity and improving motor function.
results_summary: The study found that combining botulinum toxin therapy and dynamic electrical neurostimulation with basic therapy (including massage) led to a more significant reduction in spasticity and increased range of voluntary movements in post-stroke patients compared to using these treatments separately or basic therapy alone.
population_specificity: 96 men and women with post-stroke spasticity, mean age 60.51 ± 4.9 years, in the early recovery period after ischemic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plantar massage improves static postural control during single-limb stance in patients with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: All three included studies (1 randomized controlled trial and 2 crossover studies) supported the use of plantar massage to improve static postural control in patients with CAI, indicating good-quality and consistent evidence for its efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic ankle instability (CAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of foot massage on peripheral neuropathic pain and sleep quality in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.
results_summary: The study found that foot massage significantly reduced pain levels and improved sleep quality in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. These effects were measured using VAS, DN4, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index assessments.
population_specificity: Patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma experiencing peripheral neuropathic pain.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week, each lasting 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Massage (Anma technique) followed by rest or Reiki reduces stress levels and improves quality of life in individuals attending an outpatient integrative practices clinic.
results_summary: Massage followed by rest (G1) or Reiki (G2) effectively reduced stress and improved quality of life compared to the control group (G3). The best results were observed in the mental domain of quality of life for the Massage + Reiki group (G2), highlighting Reiki's impact on mental and psychological aspects.
population_specificity: 101 individuals attending an outpatient integrative practices clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of ductal lavage (including breast massage) versus oral corticosteroids as a first-line treatment for idiopathic granulomatous mastitis (IGM).
results_summary: The study found that ductal lavage (with breast massage) had a 1-year clinical complete response (cCR) rate of >90% in non-lactational mastitis patients, with no significant adverse events reported. The trial was designed to determine if ductal lavage is non-inferior to oral corticosteroids (assumed 90% cCR rate) with a 15% non-inferiority margin.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic granulomatous mastitis (IGM).
effective_dosage: Not specified for massage (ductal lavage and breast massage protocol as previously reported).
study_duration: 1 year follow-up post-randomization (intervention duration not explicitly stated for massage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of complementary therapies, including massage, in managing cancer pain in adult palliative care patients.
results_summary: The study found that massage therapy demonstrated significant benefits in managing cancer pain, with consistent positive outcomes across the analyzed trials. In contrast, acupuncture showed contradictory results, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients in palliative care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Court-type Thai traditional massage and Senokot in relieving chronic constipation.
results_summary: Both Court-type Thai traditional massage and Senokot were effective in relieving constipation, increasing defecation frequency and the sensation of complete evacuation. However, Thai massage was superior as it resulted in normal defecations rather than watery or entirely liquid stools.
population_specificity: Forty subjects diagnosed with chronic constipation.
effective_dosage: Thai traditional abdominal massage provided regularly (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of acupoint massage and breast massage with low-frequency pulse treatment in preventing mastitis in postpartum breastfeeding women.
results_summary: Acupoint massage probably reduces the risk of mastitis and breast pain compared to routine care, while breast massage and low-frequency pulse treatment may also reduce mastitis risk, though with lower certainty of evidence. No adverse events were reported for either intervention.
population_specificity: Postpartum breastfeeding women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence on the mechanisms, benefits, and applications of manual therapy (including massage) for pain management and overall health care.
results_summary: The study highlights that manual therapy, including touch and massage, has neuromodulatory effects that mitigate pain and improve patient comfort, with potential benefits across various health conditions. It also discusses dose-response evidence and systemic impacts on health care.
population_specificity: General patient population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence, pathophysiology, and management of sexual dysfunction related to ablative surgical techniques for Benign Prostatic Enlargement (BPE), including the role of prostatic massage as a treatment option.
results_summary: The abstract mentions prostatic massage as one of the available treatment options for ejaculation disorders (retrograde ejaculation or anejaculation) but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes related to its use.
population_specificity: Men suffering from BPE and experiencing sexual dysfunction post-ablative surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of massage for reducing peri-operative anxiety in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that massage significantly reduced peri-operative anxiety across pre-, intra-, and post-operative stages, with acupoint or specific body reflex area massage showing larger effects than general massage. Both professional and non-professional massage were effective, and sessions lasting 10-20 minutes were most recommended.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing surgery (2494 participants across 25 controlled trials).
effective_dosage: 10-20 minutes per session (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of intervention not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: To investigate whether noninvasive physical therapy (including facial massage) improves facial nerve outcomes in adults with iatrogenic facial paralysis compared to no intervention.
results_summary: The study found that physical therapy (including facial massage) likely has benefit and is associated with no harm in patients with iatrogenic facial paralysis, but definitive conclusions were hindered by heterogeneity in reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with iatrogenic facial paralysis, primarily associated with parotidectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine person-centred care experienced by patients with chronic conditions consulting massage therapists and other complementary medicine practitioners.
results_summary: Patients reported high perceptions of person-centred care during consultations with massage therapists, with scores comparable to other complementary medicine practitioners. Ratings for person-centred care were higher for massage therapists than for medical doctors.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic conditions (n=29) consulting massage therapists in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tuina (therapeutic massage) is more effective and safer than no treatment or routine medical treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: Tuina combined with routine treatments may be superior to routine treatments alone for improving overall symptoms of IBS-diarrhea, but the evidence was not statistically significant for overall symptom improvement. The study noted methodological issues and heterogeneity in Tuina manipulations, calling for larger, more robust trials.
population_specificity: Patients with IBS (5 trials on IBS-diarrhea, 3 on IBS-constipation), diagnosed based on Manning or Rome criteria.
effective_dosage: Not specified (8 different manipulations were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of abdominal massage alone, polyethylene glycol (PEG) alone, and their combination in treating functional constipation.
results_summary: The combination of abdominal massage and PEG showed significant improvements in constipation symptoms, quality of life, and stool consistency compared to either treatment alone. Abdominal massage alone also improved symptoms but was less effective than the combination.
population_specificity: Patients with functional constipation based on Rome IV criteria.
effective_dosage: Abdominal massage for 15 minutes daily; PEG 20 g daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of massage therapy, alone or combined with other treatments, for relieving breast engorgement in breastfeeding women.
results_summary: Massage therapy combined with cactus and aloe compress may be more effective than massage alone for reducing breast pain, and massage plus cactus and aloe cold compress may reduce breast hardness. However, the certainty of evidence is low due to study limitations and inconsistency.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding women experiencing breast engorgement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of vacuum myofascial therapy (VT) versus a physical therapy program (PTP) including massage, ultrasound therapy, and TENS for improving pain, range of motion, disability, and quality of life in patients with non-specific neck pain.
results_summary: Both groups showed improvements in pain, disability, range of motion, and pressure pain, but only the VT group demonstrated statistically significant improvements. At one-month follow-up, the VT group maintained improvements in pain, disability, and range of motion.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight participants with non-specific neck pain.
effective_dosage: Five sessions of massage, ultrasound therapy, and TENS over two weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sensory stimulation interventions, including massage, improve sleep quality and nocturnal restlessness in nursing-home residents with dementia.
results_summary: Sensory stimulation, including massage, improved nocturnal behavioral restlessness, sleep duration, and continuation, but had negligible effects on the number of awakenings, rest-activity rhythm, and daytime sleep. High heterogeneity was noted across studies regarding treatments and patient characteristics.
population_specificity: Nursing-home residents with dementia

study_goal: To investigate the effect of aromatherapy massage with lavender oil on pain intensity and maximal mouth opening in patients with myogenous TMD.
results_summary: Aromatherapy massage with lavender oil significantly improved maximal mouth opening compared to placebo and control groups, both immediately after the intervention and at a 2-month follow-up. The control group showed the lowest improvement in mouth opening.
population_specificity: Patients with myogenous temporomandibular disorder (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of connective tissue manipulation (CTM) and abdominal massage, combined with usual care, on constipation symptoms and quality of life in patients with chronic constipation.
results_summary: Both CTM and abdominal massage significantly improved constipation severity, symptoms, and quality of life compared to usual care alone, but neither massage method was superior to the other.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic constipation.
effective_dosage: 5 sessions per week, each lasting 15-20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of aromatherapy massage (using Lavender or Citrus Aurantium essential oils) on the quality of life of hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Both aromatherapy massage groups showed significant improvement in quality of life compared to the control group (foot massage only), but there was no significant difference between the Lavender and Citrus Aurantium groups.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a multi-interventional package (including reflexology foot massage) versus lifestyle interventions alone on physiological, biochemical, and socio-psychological parameters in women with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physiological and biochemical parameters of metabolic syndrome, as well as knowledge, in both the multi-interventional (including reflexology foot massage) and lifestyle intervention groups compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Women with metabolic syndrome from self-help groups.
effective_dosage: Reflexology foot massage (specific frequency not detailed), dietary modification, moderate intensity exercise, and structured education for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of massage, in combination with analgesia, on post-caesarean section pain relief.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence regarding the effects of massage (foot and hand) plus analgesia on pain, adverse effects, vital signs, and rescue analgesic requirements. No clear conclusions could be drawn due to the poor quality of the evidence.
population_specificity: Women who underwent caesarean sections (651 participants across six studies, five of which were quasi-RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage compared to a rest period on postoperative pain scores and physiological responses in infants with complex congenital heart disease (CCHD).
results_summary: Massage was associated with lower adjusted pain scores on most days, lower daily heart and respiratory rates, and immediate improvements in physiological parameters, though no overall group effects on pain level or rate of change were observed.
population_specificity: Infants (1 day to 12 months old) with CCHD following their first cardiothoracic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the efficacy of aromatherapy, including massage, in reducing preoperative anxiety in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that aromatherapy, including massage, significantly reduced preoperative anxiety in adults, with short-length sessions (≤20 minutes) showing better effects. Lavender oil, citrus species preparations, and rose oil were particularly effective.
population_specificity: Adults awaiting surgical procedures, including cardiac and relatively low-risk surgeries.
effective_dosage: Not specified for massage specifically, but aromatherapy sessions ≤20 minutes were most effective.
study_duration: Session length varied, with ≤20 minutes being more effective.

study_goal: To evaluate the role and effects of physiotherapy interventions, including massage therapy, in alleviating symptoms for advanced cancer patients in hospice care.
results_summary: Massage therapy was found to be beneficial in reducing symptom burden and improving quality of life for advanced cancer patients in hospice care, though studies were generally of low to moderate quality.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer receiving hospice care.

study_goal: To evaluate the feasibility of Chinese massage (CM) as a treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and its potential to reduce drug use while maintaining therapeutic effects.
results_summary: CM combined with metformin significantly improved multiple glycemic and metabolic parameters, including fasting blood glucose, postprandial blood glucose, hemoglobin A1c, insulin resistance, and body mass index, while increasing the overall effective rate. The study concluded that CM has a synergistic effect with metformin, improving clinical efficacy and potentially reducing adverse reactions.
population_specificity: 769 subjects with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) across 10 studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage in reducing anxiety and depression in pregnant women.
results_summary: Meta-analysis of four studies showed a moderate effect of massage therapy on reducing depressive symptoms in pregnant women, though potential bias was noted. Massage may be more effective than usual care, but further high-quality research is needed.
population_specificity: Pregnant women over 18 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sacral massage and heat application on labor pain perception and comfort levels in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that both sacral massage and heat application significantly reduced labor pain perception compared to the control group, with heat application showing slightly better results. Additionally, heat application improved overall comfort levels more than massage or standard care.
population_specificity: Primiparous pregnant women aged 17-35 with cervical dilation of 4-5 cm.
effective_dosage: Sacral massage applied at 4-5 cm, 6-7 cm, and 8-9 cm cervical dilation (specific duration/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention administered during active labor (cervical dilation from 4-5 cm to 8-9 cm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aromatherapy massage on acute pain and dry skin following needle insertion into an arteriovenous fistula in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Aromatherapy massage significantly reduced acute pain and improved skin moisture compared to both olive-oil massage and standard care, with sustained effects at an eight-week follow-up. Olive-oil massage also reduced pain but was less effective than aromatherapy for skin moisture.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with arteriovenous fistulas in a Turkish dialysis center.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (3 times per week for 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of massage on the rehabilitation of children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The review found that massage significantly reduced muscle tone in children with CP, particularly in spastic-type CP, but no consensus existed on other effects due to limited research. The methodological quality of the included studies varied, with some being high-quality and others fair or poor.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (CP), including various types such as ataxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of Instrument Assisted Soft Tissue Mobilization (IASTM), Vibration Massage, and Light Hand Massage on hamstrings flexibility and knee proprioception in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that all three massage interventions (IASTM, Vibration Massage, and Light Hand Massage) positively influenced hamstrings flexibility immediately after a single session, but no statistically significant changes in knee proprioception were observed.
population_specificity: 16 healthy, non-injured male participants (mean age 23.7 years).
effective_dosage: 5 minutes for IASTM and Vibration Massage, 8 minutes for Light Hand Massage.
study_duration: Single session per intervention with a 1-week interval between sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of massage, EMLA cream, and their combination on physiological responses to pain from intravenous line insertion in preschool children.
results_summary: Massage alone was not effective in significantly lowering increased heart rate (HR) and respiratory rate (RR) caused by pain. Its effectiveness was more noticeable when combined with EMLA cream.
population_specificity: 3- to 6-year-old children undergoing intravenous line insertion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) massage for individuals at-risk of or living with lymphedema, particularly focusing on breast cancer-related lymphedema.
results_summary: Some studies reported positive effects of MLD on volume reduction, quality of life, and symptom-related outcomes, while others found no additional benefit when MLD was part of complex decongestive therapy. MLD may help prevent lymphedema progression in early stages post-breast cancer surgery but shows limited benefit in moderate to severe cases.
population_specificity: Female and male participants (primarily female) at-risk of or with breast cancer-related lymphedema.

study_goal: To compare the clinical outcomes of Cyriax manipulation (including pre-manipulative massage) and traditional physical therapy for cervical discogenic problems in terms of pain, range of motion, and disability.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving Cyriax manipulation and pre-manipulative massage showed significant improvements in pain, range of motion, and neck disability compared to the traditional physical therapy group (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Patients with prolapsed intervertebral disc and neck or arm pain.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of pre-manipulative massage and Cyriax manipulation protocol (specific details not provided).
study_duration: 4 days/week for an unspecified duration (study conducted over 6 months).

study_goal: The study did not investigate massage; it focused on acute exercise interventions as game day priming strategies for team-sport athletes.
results_summary: The study excluded massage as a priming strategy and did not evaluate its effects.
population_specificity: Team-sport athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of disability at 6-month follow-up in patients with medium-risk chronic non-specific low back pain (LBP) receiving multimodal physical treatments, including massage.
results_summary: The study found that lower work ability and recent consultation with a medical specialist for back pain predicted higher disability at 6 months, suggesting standard conservative care (including massage) may not adequately manage these patients' needs. Massage was part of a pragmatic multimodal approach, but its individual efficacy was not isolated.
population_specificity: 108 patients with medium-risk chronic non-specific LBP (mean age 50.4 years) from Australian chiropractic and physiotherapy clinics.
study_duration: 6 months (follow-up period; intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of acupressure on dynamic balance in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in dynamic balance, as measured by the timed up and go test (26.53% improvement) and step test for both right (35.22%) and left (32.62%) legs. The results suggest acupressure therapy is effective for improving balance in elderly women.
population_specificity: 72 elderly women aged 60-80 years in Qazvin, Iran.
effective_dosage: Rotary massage using the thumb at pressure points, 3 times a week for 20 minutes per session.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of ischemic compression (IC) technique on pain and function in individuals with shoulder pain.
results_summary: The IC technique showed immediate and short-term positive effects for pain and short-term positive effects for shoulder function in individuals with shoulder pain, though evidence is limited by study quality and lack of standardization.
population_specificity: Individuals with shoulder pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of massage as a non-invasive treatment for acute calcific periarthritis in the digits.
results_summary: The study found that massage, combined with analgesics, led to gradual pain improvement and complete resolution of the calcifying mass within 6 months, with no recurrence over a 2-year follow-up.
population_specificity: A 69-year-old woman with acute calcific periarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the left fifth finger.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hand massage could reduce nausea, vomiting, pain, fear, and stress in children aged 7-11 after circumcision.
results_summary: Hand massage did not significantly reduce postoperative nausea and vomiting compared to the control group. However, the study did not report specific pain, fear, or stress outcomes for the massage group, only noting significant differences for music therapy and kaleidoscope interventions.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-11 undergoing circumcision in a Turkish hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on sports massage therapy's effects on sports performance, recovery, and musculoskeletal conditions.
results_summary: The study found a lack of high-quality research on sports massage therapy, indicating a need for further investigation to better understand its effects on performance and musculoskeletal conditions.
population_specificity: Athletes and individuals with musculoskeletal conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short-term effects of myofascial induction (a form of massage) on mechanosensitivity of upper limb nerves in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: A single myofascial induction session improved mechanosensitivity in affected upper limb nerves (median, radial, and ulnar) and had positive effects on symptom mechanosensitivity, particularly for the ulnar nerve. No significant improvements were observed in nonaffected nerves.
population_specificity: 21 breast cancer survivors with stage I-IIIA cancer.
study_duration: Single session with a 4-week washout period between crossover sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of foot and back massage on blood pressure and sleep quality in females with essential hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that six sessions of foot and back massage significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure and improved sleep quality, with strong statistical significance (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Females with essential hypertension (n=90, 60 in intervention groups, 30 in control group).
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, twice weekly for 3 weeks (total of 6 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if massage interventions in trials reflect real-life delivery and whether quality of life measures capture perceived benefits reported in qualitative studies.
results_summary: The study found that none of the trials included all key delivery components of massage, and quality of life scales failed to capture the full range of perceived benefits, often including irrelevant items.
population_specificity: Palliative care patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of complementary and alternative therapy methods, including massage, for treating infantile colic.
results_summary: Massage was found to effectively reduce the symptoms of infantile colic, with no serious side effects reported. The study included multiple interventions, with massage showing positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Infants with colic in the first three months of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ostrich oil massage on the severity of pruritus and quality of life in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Ostrich oil massage significantly reduced pruritus severity in hemodialysis patients by the third and fourth weeks of treatment compared to placebo, but no significant difference in quality of life was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with pruritus (n=68).
effective_dosage: 1 mL ostrich oil applied to the pruritus area for 10 min each night.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a manual therapy technique using moderate digital pressure in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effectiveness of the massage technique.
population_specificity: Women with fibromyalgia.
effective_dosage: Moderate digital pressure (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of tactile/kinesthetic massage therapy on growth and body composition parameters in preterm infants.
results_summary: Massage therapy significantly increased daily weight gain, growth velocity, total body mass, fat mass (total/legs), lean mass (total/arms/legs/trunk), and bone mineral density (arms/legs/trunk) compared to routine care. The study concluded that massage therapy improves growth quality by enhancing lean mass and bone mineral density while promoting peripheral fat distribution.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (< 32 weeks gestation) at a corrected gestational age of 35 weeks.
